item.title: The 20 photographs of the week
item.trailText: The continuing crisis in Syria, the South Carolina church shooting, the 200th anniversary of the Battle of Waterloo – the best photography in news, culture and sport from around the world this week
item.standFirst:
The continuing crisis in Syria, the South Carolina church shooting, the 200th anniversary of the Battle of Waterloo – the best photography in news, culture and sport from around the world this week.

Warning: this gallery includes graphic images that some readers may find disturbing

displayImages.caption: Dylann Storm Roof appears on closed-circuit televison at his bond hearing in Charleston, South Carolina, in a still image taken from video. A 21-year-old white man has been charged with nine counts of murder in connection with an attack on a historic black South Carolina church, police said, and media reports said he had hoped to incite a race war in the US. Photograph: Pool/Reuters
displayImages.altText: Dylann Storm Roof appears on closed-circuit televison at his bond hearing in Charleston, South Carolina, in a still image taken from video. A 21-year-old white man has been charged with nine counts of murder in connection with an attack on a historic black South Carolina church, police said, and media reports said he had hoped to incite a race war in the US.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Dylann Storm Roof appears on closed-circuit televison at his bond hearing in Charleston, South Carolina, in a still image taken from video. A 21-year-old white man has been charged with nine counts of murder in connection with an attack on a historic black South Carolina church, police said, and media reports said he had hoped to incite a race war in the US.

displayImages.caption: Barbara Lloyd cries as she joins hands with mourners during the singing of ‘We Shall Overcome’ at a memorial service for the victims of the shooting at the Emanuel AME church in Charleston. NAACP (National Association for the Advancement of Colored People) national president Cornell William Brooks called the shooting an ‘act of racial terrorism’ and also said that the confederate flag ‘must come down’ from the South Carolina state capitol. Photograph: David Goldman/AP
displayImages.altText: Barbara Lloyd cries as she joins hands with mourners during the singing of 'We Shall Overcome' at a memorial service for the victims of the shooting at the Emanuel AME Church in Charleston. NAACP (National Association for the Advancement of Colored People) national president Cornell William Brooks called the shooting an ‘act of racial terrorism’ and also said that the confederate flag ‘must come down’ from the South Carolina state capitol.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Barbara Lloyd cries as she joins hands with mourners during the singing of ‘We Shall Overcome’ at a memorial service for the victims of the shooting at the Emanuel AME church in Charleston. NAACP (National Association for the Advancement of Colored People) national president Cornell William Brooks called the shooting an ‘act of racial terrorism’ and also said that the confederate flag ‘must come down’ from the South Carolina state capitol.

displayImages.caption: The men of Omega Psi Phi Fraternity Inc lead a crowd of people in prayer outside the Emanuel AME church after a memorial in Charleston. President Barack Obama said: ‘at some point, we as a country will have to reckon with the fact that this type of mass violence does not happen in other advanced countries.’ Photograph: Stephen B Morton/AP
displayImages.altText: The men of Omega Psi Phi Fraternity Inc lead a crowd of people in prayer outside the Emanuel AME Church after a memorial in Charleston. President Barack Obama said, 'at some point, we as a country will have to reckon with the fact that this type of mass violence does not happen in other advanced countries'.
displayImages.cleanCaption: The men of Omega Psi Phi Fraternity Inc lead a crowd of people in prayer outside the Emanuel AME church after a memorial in Charleston. President Barack Obama said: ‘at some point, we as a country will have to reckon with the fact that this type of mass violence does not happen in other advanced countries.’

displayImages.caption: Syrians fleeing the war head towards the border gates at the Akcakale crossing in Sanliurfa province. Turkish officials said that measures were being taken to limit the flow of Syrian refugees onto its territory after an influx of thousands over the last few days due to the fighting between Isis and Kurdish forces. Under an ‘open-door’ policy, Turkey has taken in 1.8m Syrian refugees since the conflict erupted in 2011 Photograph: Bulent Kilic/AFP/Getty
displayImages.altText: Syrians fleeing the war head towards the border gates at the Akcakale crossing in Sanliurfa province. Turkish officials said that measures were being taken to limit the flow of Syrian refugees onto its territory after an influx of thousands over the last few days due to the fighting between Isis and Kurdish forces. Under an ‘open-door’ policy, Turkey has taken in 1.8m Syrian refugees since the conflict erupted in 2011.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Syrians fleeing the war head towards the border gates at the Akcakale crossing in Sanliurfa province. Turkish officials said that measures were being taken to limit the flow of Syrian refugees onto its territory after an influx of thousands over the last few days due to the fighting between Isis and Kurdish forces. Under an ‘open-door’ policy, Turkey has taken in 1.8m Syrian refugees since the conflict erupted in 2011

displayImages.caption: Here, in another photograph from the Akcakale crossing, a Syrian refugee holds onto his daughter as they attempt to cross into Turkey. The refugees had fled from the town of Tel Abiad due to impending fighting between Isis and Kurdish forces there. A few minutes after this photograph was taken, the Turkish officials allowed them to cross the border into Turkey Photograph: Umit Bektas/Reuters
displayImages.altText: Here, in another photograph from the Akcakale crossing, a Syrian refugee holds onto his daughter as they attempt to cross into Turkey. The refugees had fled from the town of Tel Abiad due to impending fighting between Isis and Kurdish forces there. A few minutes after this photograph was taken, the Turkish officials allowed them to cross the border into Turkey.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Here, in another photograph from the Akcakale crossing, a Syrian refugee holds onto his daughter as they attempt to cross into Turkey. The refugees had fled from the town of Tel Abiad due to impending fighting between Isis and Kurdish forces there. A few minutes after this photograph was taken, the Turkish officials allowed them to cross the border into Turkey

displayImages.caption: A wounded Syrian child receives treatment at a makeshift medical centre in the rebel-held town of Douma. Heavy shelling and air strikes by government forces injured many children, according to the Syrian Observatory of Human Rights Photograph: Abd Doumany/AFP/Getty
displayImages.altText: A wounded Syrian child receives treatment at a makeshift medical centre in the rebel-held town of Douma. Heavy shelling and air strikes by government forces injured many children, according to the Syrian Observatory of Human Rights.
displayImages.cleanCaption: A wounded Syrian child receives treatment at a makeshift medical centre in the rebel-held town of Douma. Heavy shelling and air strikes by government forces injured many children, according to the Syrian Observatory of Human Rights

displayImages.caption: Syrian migrants search for their missing passports in the sea after their arrival at the Greek island of Lesvos Photograph: Thanassis Stavrakis/AP
displayImages.altText: Syrian migrants search for their missing passports in the sea after their arrival at the Greek island of Lesvos.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Syrian migrants search for their missing passports in the sea after their arrival at the Greek island of Lesvos

displayImages.caption: People stand by the destroyed embankment of the Vere river in Tbilisi. At least 13 people died due to severe flooding in the capital of Georgia Photograph: Pavel Golovkin/AP
displayImages.altText: People stand by the destroyed embankment of the Vere River in Tbilisi. At least 13 people died due to severe flooding in the capital of Georgia.
displayImages.cleanCaption: People stand by the destroyed embankment of the Vere river in Tbilisi. At least 13 people died due to severe flooding in the capital of Georgia

displayImages.caption: A hippopotamus stands in the mud after escaping from a flooded zoo in Tbilisi. Tigers, lions, a hippopotamus and other animals fled from the zoo after the heavy flooding destroyed their enclosures. See more images from the Tbilisi floods here Photograph: Beso Gulashvili/AP
displayImages.altText: A hippopotamus stands in the mud after escaping from a flooded zoo in Tbilisi. Tigers, lions, a hippopotamus and other animals fled from the zoo after the heavy flooding destroyed their enclosures.
displayImages.cleanCaption: A hippopotamus stands in the mud after escaping from a flooded zoo in Tbilisi. Tigers, lions, a hippopotamus and other animals fled from the zoo after the heavy flooding destroyed their enclosures. See more images from the Tbilisi floods here

displayImages.caption: An excavator removes a dead bear from the zoo in Tbilisi. Georgia police were accused of unnecessarily shooting zoo animals in the wake of the floods in which the zoo lost half of its animals Photograph: David Mdzinarishvili/Reuters
displayImages.altText: An excavator removes a dead bear from the zoo in Tbilisi. Georgia police were accused of unnecessarily shooting zoo animals in wake of the floods in which the zoo lost half of its animals.
displayImages.cleanCaption: An excavator removes a dead bear from the zoo in Tbilisi. Georgia police were accused of unnecessarily shooting zoo animals in the wake of the floods in which the zoo lost half of its animals

displayImages.caption: In Calais, a French anti-riot police officer tries to prevent illegal migrants from hiding in trucks heading for England Photograph: Philippe Huguen/AFP/Getty
displayImages.altText: In Calais, a French anti-riot police officer tries to prevent illegal migrants from hiding in trucks heading for England.
displayImages.cleanCaption: In Calais, a French anti-riot police officer tries to prevent illegal migrants from hiding in trucks heading for England

displayImages.caption: Israeli soldiers take part in a military exercise at the Israeli-annexed Golan Heights. An alliance of rebel fighters in Syria are battling president Bashar al-Assad’s regime forces for the control of the country’s Quneitra province, which lies on the Syrian side of the Golan Heights. Israeli authorities said that the country was preparing for the possibility that refugees fleeing fighting in the area might seek to cross to the Israeli-occupied side of the strategic plateau Photograph: Menahem Kahana/AFP/Getty
displayImages.altText: Israeli soldiers take part in a military exercise at the Israeli-annexed Golan Heights. An alliance of rebel fighters in Syria are battling president Bashar al-Assad’s regime forces for the control of the country’s Quneitra province, which lies on the Syrian side of the Golan Heights. Israeli authorities said that the country was preparing for the possibility that refugees fleeing fighting in the area might seek to cross to the Israeli-occupied side of the strategic plateau.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Israeli soldiers take part in a military exercise at the Israeli-annexed Golan Heights. An alliance of rebel fighters in Syria are battling president Bashar al-Assad’s regime forces for the control of the country’s Quneitra province, which lies on the Syrian side of the Golan Heights. Israeli authorities said that the country was preparing for the possibility that refugees fleeing fighting in the area might seek to cross to the Israeli-occupied side of the strategic plateau

displayImages.caption: Palestinians, not permitted by Israeli security forces to cross into Jerusalem from the West Bank, climb over a section of the controversial barrier in an attempt to attend the first Friday prayer of Ramadan in Jerusalem’s al-Aqsa mosque Photograph: Mohamad Torokman/Reuters
displayImages.altText: Palestinians, not permitted by Israeli security forces to cross into Jerusalem from the West Bank, climb over a section of the controversial barrier in an attempt to attend the first Friday prayer of Ramadan in Jerusalem's al-Aqsa mosque
displayImages.cleanCaption: Palestinians, not permitted by Israeli security forces to cross into Jerusalem from the West Bank, climb over a section of the controversial barrier in an attempt to attend the first Friday prayer of Ramadan in Jerusalem’s al-Aqsa mosque

displayImages.caption: A donkey and cart move through the dust and rubble of bombed homes that still wait to be demolished or rebuilt in Gaza City. The devastation across the city can still be seen nearly a year on from the conflict between Israel and Palestinian militants. Money pledged by the international community six months ago to rebuild Gaza has not yet materialised Photograph: Christopher Furlong/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: A donkey and cart move through the dust and rubble of bombed homes that still wait to be demolished or rebuilt in Gaza City. The devastation across the city can still be seen nearly a year on from the conflict between Israel and Palestinian militants. Money pledged by the international community six months ago to rebuild Gaza has not yet materialised.
displayImages.cleanCaption: A donkey and cart move through the dust and rubble of bombed homes that still wait to be demolished or rebuilt in Gaza City. The devastation across the city can still be seen nearly a year on from the conflict between Israel and Palestinian militants. Money pledged by the international community six months ago to rebuild Gaza has not yet materialised

displayImages.caption: Volcanic ash from Mount Sinabung fills the sky over an abandoned church during another eruption in Karo, Indonesia. According to the National Disaster Mitigation Agency, more than 10,000 villagers have fled their homes since the authorities raised the alert status of Mount Sinabung to the highest level Photograph: Sutanta Aditya/AFP/Getty
displayImages.altText: Volcanic ash from Mount Sinabung fills the sky over an abandoned church during another eruption in Karo, Indonesia. According to the National Disaster Mitigation Agency, more than 10,000 villagers have fled their homes since the authorities raised the alert status of Mount Sinabung to the highest level.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Volcanic ash from Mount Sinabung fills the sky over an abandoned church during another eruption in Karo, Indonesia. According to the National Disaster Mitigation Agency, more than 10,000 villagers have fled their homes since the authorities raised the alert status of Mount Sinabung to the highest level

displayImages.caption: Russian servicemen maintain a pontoon bridge during the opening of the ‘Army 2015’ international military forum in Kubinka, Russia Photograph: Maxim Shemetov/Reuters
displayImages.altText: Russian servicemen maintain a pontoon bridge during the opening of the 'Army 2015' international military forum in Kubinka, Russia.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Russian servicemen maintain a pontoon bridge during the opening of the ‘Army 2015’ international military forum in Kubinka, Russia

displayImages.caption: Personal belongings are photographed by Sergei Ilnitsky in a destroyed home in Donetsk, Ukraine Photograph: Sergei Ilnitsky/EPA
displayImages.altText: Personal belongings are photographed by Sergei Ilnitsky in a destroyed home in Donetsk, Ukraine.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Personal belongings are photographed by Sergei Ilnitsky in a destroyed home in Donetsk, Ukraine

displayImages.caption: Historical re-enactors practise their roles in the Allied Bivouac camp at Waterloo, Belgium. Around 5,000 re-enactors from around the world are taking part in events to mark the 200th anniversary of the Battle of Waterloo. The 1815 battle saw the overthrow of Napoleon Bonaparte and the restoration of Louis XVIII to the French throne Photograph: Dan Kitwood/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Historical re-enactors practice their roles in the Allied Bivouac camp at Waterloo, Belgium. Around 5,000 re-enactors from around the world are taking part in events to mark the 200th anniversary of the Battle of Waterloo. The 1815 battle saw the overthrow of Napoleon Bonaparte and the restoration of Louis XVIII to the French throne.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Historical re-enactors practise their roles in the Allied Bivouac camp at Waterloo, Belgium. Around 5,000 re-enactors from around the world are taking part in events to mark the 200th anniversary of the Battle of Waterloo. The 1815 battle saw the overthrow of Napoleon Bonaparte and the restoration of Louis XVIII to the French throne

displayImages.caption: Protesters in downtown Santiago, Chile, are hit by a petrol bomb during a demonstration called for by students and teachers demanding education reforms Photograph: Andres Stapff/Reuters
displayImages.altText: Protesters are hit by a petrol bomb during a demonstration called for by students and teachers in downtown Santiago, Chile.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Protesters in downtown Santiago, Chile, are hit by a petrol bomb during a demonstration called for by students and teachers demanding education reforms

displayImages.caption: Argentina’s Nicolás Otamendi jumps over Uruguay’s Marcelo Lodeiro during their Copa América match at Estadio La Portada in La Serena, Chile. Sergio Agüero’s diving header gave Argentina a 1-0 victory Photograph: Marcos Brindicci/Reuters
displayImages.altText: Argentina's Nicolas Otamendi jumps over Uruguay's Marcelo Lodeiro during their Copa América match at Estadio La Portada in La Serena, Chile. Sergio Agüero’s diving header gave Argentina a 1-0 victory.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Argentina’s Nicolás Otamendi jumps over Uruguay’s Marcelo Lodeiro during their Copa América match at Estadio La Portada in La Serena, Chile. Sergio Agüero’s diving header gave Argentina a 1-0 victory
